Literature Review: Understanding inhomogeneous and anisotropic fluid flows is a critical area of research in fluid dynamics, particularly because these flows are prevalent in many natural and industrial settings. Unlike homogeneous and isotropic turbulence, which has been extensively studied and is relatively well-understood, inhomogeneous and anisotropic turbulence presents unique challenges due to its spatial and directional variations. This literature review aims to summarize recent developments in the theories of inhomogeneous and anisotropic turbulence, with a particular focus on quasi-linear approximations and their statistical formulations. Recent advancements in the field have highlighted the importance of quasi-linear approximations (QLAs) in capturing the essential features of inhomogeneous and anisotropic turbulence. QLAs are a class of models that simplify the complex interactions between different scales of motion by treating the nonlinear terms in the Navier-Stokes equations as perturbations. This approach allows for a more tractable analysis of the flow dynamics while retaining key physical insights. One significant development in this area is the work by Mininni et al. (2019), who explored the use of QLAs in the context of magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) turbulence. They demonstrated that QLAs can effectively capture the anisotropic nature of MHD turbulence, particularly in the presence of a strong mean magnetic field. Their findings suggest that QLAs can provide a useful framework for understanding the complex interactions between magnetic fields and fluid motions in astrophysical and laboratory plasmas. Another important contribution comes from Cambon and Jacquin (1992), who developed a spectral closure model for inhomogeneous turbulence. Their model, based on the quasi-normal approximation, provides a systematic way to account for the effects of inhomogeneity and anisotropy on the energy transfer processes in turbulent flows. This work has been influential in the development of more advanced statistical models for inhomogeneous turbulence. The role of statistical formulations in the study of inhomogeneous and anisotropic turbulence has also been a focal point of recent research. For instance, Galtier and Banerjee (2017) investigated the statistical properties of anisotropic turbulence using a wave turbulence approach. They showed that the wave turbulence framework can accurately describe the energy cascade in anisotropic flows, providing a new perspective on the statistical behavior of these systems. In addition to theoretical developments, numerical simulations have played a crucial role in advancing our understanding of inhomogeneous and anisotropic turbulence. For example, Porte-Agel et al. (2000) conducted large-eddy simulations (LES) of atmospheric boundary layer flows, which are inherently inhomogeneous and anisotropic. Their simulations revealed the importance of coherent structures in the energy transfer processes and highlighted the need for more sophisticated subgrid-scale models to accurately capture the dynamics of these flows. The application of machine learning techniques to the analysis of inhomogeneous and anisotropic turbulence has also gained traction in recent years. Wang et al. (2020) applied deep learning algorithms to predict the evolution of turbulent flows in complex geometries. Their results showed that machine learning models can effectively capture the intricate patterns of inhomogeneity and anisotropy, offering a promising avenue for future research. Despite these advances, several open questions remain in the field. One of the most pressing issues is the development of more accurate and computationally efficient models for inhomogeneous and anisotropic turbulence. While QLAs and statistical models have made significant progress, they often rely on simplifying assumptions that may not hold in all practical scenarios. For instance, the assumption of quasi-normality in spectral closure models can lead to inaccuracies in the prediction of higher-order moments of the velocity field. Another challenge is the integration of experimental data into theoretical and computational models. Experimental studies, such as those conducted by Mydlarski and Warhaft (1996) on grid-generated turbulence, provide valuable insights into the behavior of inhomogeneous and anisotropic flows. However, bridging the gap between experimental observations and theoretical predictions remains a significant challenge. Furthermore, the role of small-scale intermittency in inhomogeneous and anisotropic turbulence is still not fully understood. Intermittency, characterized by the sporadic and localized nature of energy dissipation, can significantly affect the statistical properties of turbulent flows. Recent work by Biferale et al. (2018) has shed light on the intermittent behavior of anisotropic turbulence, but more research is needed to develop a comprehensive theory that accounts for these effects. In conclusion, recent developments in the theories of inhomogeneous and anisotropic turbulence have provided valuable insights into the complex dynamics of these flows. Quasi-linear approximations and statistical formulations have emerged as powerful tools for analyzing and modeling inhomogeneous and anisotropic turbulence. However, several open questions and challenges remain, including the development of more accurate models, the integration of experimental data, and the understanding of small-scale intermittency. Addressing these issues will require continued interdisciplinary efforts and the application of advanced computational and analytical techniques.
